segments.text: This is an interview with Dr. Thomas J. Kozik, professor of mechanical engineering.
Today's date is October 1, 1981.
Let's begin, Dr. Kozik, by your telling us something about your early years, where you were born, when, and so forth.
I was born in Jersey City, New Jersey, on April the 9th, 1930.
The section of Jersey City was the downtown section, which was the
landing spot for most of the immigrants who came from Europe.
My mother and my father both came from Poland.
In the early years, downtown Jersey City was broken up into three ethnic areas.
There was the Polish area, there was the Italian area, and then there was the Irish area.
But in reality, the Irish area wasn't a single identifiable area because the Irish happened to rule the city.
These were the days of Mayor Haig and the political machine.
The Poles and the Italians provided most of the physical labor force for Jersey City.
That labor force typically was employed on the docks, was employed in the, not stock markets, but slaughterhouses, and was employed in the various warehouses.
This was backbreaking type of work.
I didn't speak English until I was age six because there was no need to in my section.
People in the various ethnic areas spoke the language and maintained the culture of their home country.
Upon going to parochial school, I learned and began to speak English, graduated from parochial school, and then went to Ferris High School, which was the public high school at the RRIS.
This was the public high school for the downtown residents.
Having graduated from Ferris, I was very fortunate to be accepted to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
That was rather unique because no one from the downtown area.
That's up in Troy, New York.
Let me ask you about your parents.
What did your father do for a living?
came to this country in about 1904-1905 as a young man from what is now Poland, but in those days was simply a part of the territory of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
He was, I believe, 16, he tells me, and his prime reason for leaving Poland was he was about to be drafted into the Austrian army.
And many immigrants in those days wanted nothing to do with the service, and so he fled from Poland
and went to, I believe, Hamburg and saved and got enough money together to come to this country on steerage.
My father always told me that he literally hid behind a woman's skirt because he mentioned that in crossing the border, there were passport checks.
And the Austrian government was very concerned about keeping people in, especially people of military age.

So, as he was crossing the border from what was then the Polish territory into the German territory, the inspector came along the train, and a group of peasant women with their long flowing skirts were sitting on a bench, and they knew what the situation was, and my father looked panicky, and they told him quick to get onto the bench, which he did, and then they spread their skirts over him, and the inspector never saw them.
Years later, when I was drafted into the army, my father told me that he thought I was the failure in the family.
I wasn't able to escape the draft.
At any rate, he came to this country.
Well, he came across on steerage, and he told something about the trips and the steerage trip itself.
Basically, it was a hole in which all of the immigrants were put in.
Probably by our present standards, we would have considered it being unsanitary and a crowded situation.
But for those days, it was simply normal, and the people were just delighted
to be leaving their countries, not only from Poland, but from most of the Eastern European countries.
Food was served in a large pot.
You had a community dish, community label.
My father still tells me that there were the two Russians, somewhere from deep inside of Russia.
And he said they were pleasant men, but obviously untutored and uncultured.
The choice piece of food
This stew that they would invariably bring was the meat with the fat on it.

And when they would bring the pot over, one of these Russians would walk over, roll up his sleeve, and just shove his hand into this hot boiling mess just to get out this slimy piece of fat food and proceed to eat it, much to the disgust of all of the other passengers.
And they finally complained and got the captain down.

The captain came down, listened to their complaints, and then lined up the two Russians against the wall and told them that if he should ever hear of this again, he would personally have them thrown overboard.
And so that ended that particular incident.
He came and landed at Ellis Island, which was at that time the major disembarkation point for most of the immigrants.
And when I asked him what it is that they checked on, he said really only two things, eyes and syphilis.
If you could see and a medical check showed that you didn't have syphilis, that was it.
And so he passed through Ellis Island in about five minutes, was released, and from that point on he was on his own.
It was literally the new country.
He worked at a variety of jobs.
By the time my mother met him, he had a little store which sold musical goods.
I wouldn't say it was a terribly successful one, but my father was a bachelor for a number of years.
In fact, he didn't get married until he was about 40 or 41.
And for his purposes, it was sufficient to keep body and soul together.
And so that was what his business was.
My mother got a hold of him, and she looked at it and realized that the music business was not the kind of thing you could depend on to raise a family.
And so she started to introduce furniture.

and the store finally became known as Grove Music and Furniture Company, which sounds very prestigious, but in reality was a small rinky-dink store that catered primarily to the immigrant groups in downtown Jersey City.
The music portion was the concession my mother had to make to my father, who still had this great love for music.
He himself played an accordion.
Your mother was already living
them had come from Poland to this country.
And so my mother and my father were married.
My mother's background is quite different.

She came from a little town called Przemysl, which is right on the P-R-Z-E-M-Y-S-L. And the last L is really a Polish L, which is an L with a little diagonal out through it, which gives it a different accent mark.
In reality, the town was called Shenyava, which is sort of the outskirts of Kremish.
Shenyava would be S-I-E-N-I-A-W-A.
And my mother and her aunt was also, or her sister was here in this country, still talk about the time before the First World War, that when winter would come,
And the River Son, which is the river that separated the Polish border from the Russian border, would freeze over.
S-A-N.
The wolves would come down from the Russian forests foraging for food, and they would come into the villages.

And it wasn't unusual in those days to open up the window of the cottage, and by window it means a shuttered board because there were no glass panes, and find yourself looking face to face with a Russian timber wolf.
And one of the stories that comes as a result of that, my wife happened to write up in a children's magazine, it was the story about my grandfather played the fiddle for the wolves.
And it literally was true.
My grandfather, like most of the people in that part of the country, would play some musical instrument.
It was their form of recreation.
And he would play at various wedding feasts.
And they would go from town to town.
The town perhaps were not more than one or two miles apart, or one kilometer to two kilometers.
But the only transportation you had was your own feet.
And this one winter, my grandfather had played at this one wedding in this one town and was coming back.
And he played the bull fiddle.
And as he was walking in the snow, he looked up at the ridge and he suddenly realized there were three or four wolves on that ridge tracking him.
This had been a particularly bitter, cold winter.
And under such circumstances, the wolves were known to attack people.
Normally, the wolf would try to shy away from people and attacks on people, per se, were fairly rare.
But nevertheless, people were aware that under extreme provocation of hunger, a wolf would come down.
And my grandfather realized that with the heavy clothing he had, there was no chance to outrun it.
And the wolves apparently were there for some rather gruesome business.
They were looking for food, and he happened to be the prime source.
So he didn't know what to do.
And by this time, the wolves started to come down and circle him.
They got an idea, and he took out the bass fiddle.
And as the wolf came within about 30 to 40 yards of him, he took the bow and strung it across the fiddle.
and then stop the wolves in their track because they just weren't aware what the sound could be.
But they'd come, stop and come back and start approaching him again and again.
He would take the bow and draw it against the fiddle and did this a number of times until we so panicked the wolves that they ran away.
And so from that time on, he was known as the man who played the fiddle for the wolves.
But my mother stayed on in Poland.
Unlike my father, she didn't leave before the First World War.
She stayed in this little village during the war itself.
And Przemysl was the jumping-off place in both wars for the German attack on Russia.
And so in this little village, she watched the Austrian army make its preparations for the invasion of Russia.
The troops were garrisoned in the town.
And in those days, you still had bayonet chargers and cavalry chargers.
And so they met the Russians.
And just outside of the town, there was some sort of a gory battle scene.
After the battle was over, the dead and the dying would lie along the field.
And in Poland, I would assume it's a raven.
It's a blackbird.
It would come down, being a scavenger bird, and peck.
at the cadavers, but worst of all, would peck at the eyes.
And for a wounded man who couldn't bring his hand up to defend his face, it would mean that he faced blindness.

And so the Austrian army rounded up all of the children in the two villages, including my mother's, gave them long sticks, marched them out into the battlefield, and had them go along among the wounded and the dead to beat away these ravens, lest they peck out the eyes of the living.
That had a very lasting impression on my mother.
My mother from that point on became a pacifist, almost a militant pacifist.
She watched the war and that was not the end of it because, of course, the Austrians invaded Russia and did beat the Germans, and did beat the Russians.
The Russians in turn regrouped, came back and proceeded to take advantage of the Austrians and in fact had beaten them.
And then I believe it's under Hindenburg, not even sure if that's him or not.
At any rate, the Prussians came in and of course they now proceeded to come and beat
the Russians again.
So you had three armies marching through this one little town.
First the Austrians, then the Russians, and then the Russians and the Austrians.
In each case there were battles, in each case there was the gory mutilation of man.
And this left quite an effect on my mother.
She remembers once a, I guess it was an Austrian captain who was
Well, he wasn't kept.
He actually took over, commandeered their home.

And at the supper meal, he brought in food from the garrison to feed my mother's family and began to weep and told my mother's family how they reminded him of his own family and also predicted his own death, which in fact did occur the following day.
Of course, when peace came, Poland was created.
And my mother did not want to stay in this small town.
She knew she had more abilities than the town possibly could give her.
Yet in those days, it was difficult for a peasant to get any education.
And so she decided that the only way she could get gymnasium, which is the same as our schools here, is to become a nun.
And so she joined the nunnery.

and she had a rather idealistic view of the church at that time thinking that once you got in to a nunnery that regardless of your state of birth that if you had ability you would be able to do things and rise to whatever position you aspire to and what she found was that again politics existed even within the church she went there she did go to school but she also found out that the
Daughters of the wealthy became the teachers.
The daughters of the peasants became the scully maids.
And so about the time it came for her to take a final vow, she decided that this was no great advantage to her.
And so she left the convent and took off to Warsaw to become a seamstress.
And she was semi-adopted by a family in Warsaw, wife of a banker.
although she was officially the seamstress for the woman.
The woman, who was childless, tended to look at my mother as being sort of a type of daughter.
She was treated very well.
And then about this time, the Polish Revolution takes place.
Well, Pisudski comes into power.
P-I, again, this L, S-U-D-S-K-I.
I think it was Beck.
at that time was the president of Poland.

Pisudski was a socialist, and they, Pisudski was accused of high crimes against the government, but Pisudski also was a hero of the newly created state of Poland in that he was able to stop the Trotskyites at the gates of Warsaw, and so he had a tremendous allegiance from the army.
Well, Pisudski was tried by the government for treason, and he was
slated to be shot at 3 o'clock on a Friday afternoon.
The place where he was going to be executed was not that far from where my mother's apartment was, or really the banker's wife's apartment.
This was on Alea...
I believe it may be called now Alea Pisudskiego, but I'm not quite sure what the original name was.
At any rate, it was one of the fashionable streets in Warsaw.
By 11 o'clock that morning, the train started to come in from the outskirts, bringing in the Polish troops, the people who were loyal to Pisudski.
In other words, a coup d'etat was in the making.
And finally, it erupted into battle.
And part of the battle was fought outside of this apartment where my mother was living.
And she was able to look down at the square.
And the government

trying to stymie the military takeover had thrown in cadets from the military academy to fight against the regulars and it was slaughter and she happened again to witness this bloodbath outside of her window and again a sort of cynicism came through again because she watched the priests go among the wounded and for a pole who almost invariably is a catholic
The communion rites, the last rites, are extremely, extremely important.
And she said she remembers watching the priest going among the dying.
And in many cases, you couldn't distinguish who was the soldier from the field, who was the cadet.
Both wore the same uniforms.
And he would say in Polish, ,, which means left or right.
Pisudski was considered the leftist.
The rightist was the government.
And if you happen to say, , the police would deny you the last rights.
Well, Pisudski obviously wins.
And the government is overthrown.
Pisudski becomes the dictator.
And it's by this time my mother is so disillusioned and so disgusted with the bloodbaths, the social intrigue, that she leaves for this country.
And she said, when she got on the boat, I forgot where she left from, perhaps .
She said, unlike most of the other people who were looking back, crying, she just turned her back on Poland.
She said, that was the end.
There was nothing there.
She came to this country.
She landed in Jersey City.
And she proceeded to work in a shirt factory.
This is part-time work.
And apparently, training that she had received in Warsaw as a seamstress,
was to her advantage because she stopped to make good money.
Well, of course, she landed again in this downtown Polish community.
This is true of most of the immigrants.
There was a certain comfort in that you knew the language and the culture, and the people tended to look after each other.
Did your mother learn English?
Yes, in a sense.
Her English now, she'll say, is fairly good, but it's almost not understandable.
Nevertheless, she communicates very, very well.
a combination of hand gestures, a great deal of screaming, and a great deal of coquettishness.
Her English was never as good as my father's.

My father was fairly good in English, but so very often when he would use English, although you would get the content of the message, you wouldn't get the content of the meaning because so often when you translate from another language, you tend to just give the words rather than to be able to express yourself.
When do you want me to stop?
Is there any reason why your mother and father happened to be in Jersey City, or was it just happening that way?
Well, it happened that way because remember, Jersey City is two and a half minutes away from New York City.
And in the New York City, Jersey City, Hoboken area, this was just an actual residing place for people who got off the boat.
As a six-year-old, did you have difficulty learning English, or did it come pretty easy?
Do you know I can't even remember?
Because the parochial school I had gone to was bilingual.
I studied Polish history, American history, Polish grammar, American grammar, English grammar.
So it was completely bilingual.
The nuns who taught were also bilingual.
that I'm aware of, plus the fact that on the streets you spoke English.
In those days, to have an accent or to speak another language meant that you were immediately labeled a greenhorn.
And so there was peer pressure to try to get rid of the vestiges of the other language, the other culture.
And for that reason, many people of my age who are first generation, whether they're Polish, Italian, or what have you,
tend to have forgotten their language because the peer pressure tended to try to make you forget it.
At home, even though your parents would speak in one language, you would proceed to answer them in English.
Do you speak Polish now on a regular basis?
Yes, every time I speak with my mother.
Plus the fact that I've tried to keep up with it at any chance that I'd have, I tried to practice with it.
Let me get your idea on how you as a young boy were affected by the Depression, also how your family was affected.
I think, physically, I wasn't affected in the sense that I was not hungry and I was not without clothes.
Of course, I was born in 1930, which means at the peak of the Depression, this is my growing up period of time.
I always had food when I wanted it, and I had clothes when I wanted it.
It wasn't by any means the best of clothes or anything of this sort.
But again, if you're born into it,
and everybody else is in the same circumstance, you're not aware that you're either discriminated or you're poverty-stricken.
And this was probably true also of the culture.
I'm sure by present standards now we would say we were culturally deprived, but no one realized it.
You know, this was the normal state of being.
Our recreational area were the streets of the city and the docks of Jersey City.
And in many ways, they were far more exciting than anything anyone could ever construct now.
The general rule of play was you left the house at 8 o'clock in the morning, and you went out and played with your playmates or did whatever you want, and you came back at 10 o'clock at night.
The only rule was that don't have the policeman bring you home, which meant that you learned to cope with life individually, by yourself, at a much earlier age.
than perhaps, say, a child growing up in a suburban area.
You got your knocks, you came back with your cuts, you got into your tussles with your peer groups and alien peer groups, but you learned to accommodate very quickly.
You developed your own game, stickball, which is uniquely a city game.
It's a thing that developed in people trying to have recreation within close confines.
We played football of a type that nobody here has ever seen because nobody could afford a football.
In fact, I didn't see a football, a real football, until I was about 15 years old.
A football was a bunch of newspapers wrapped around tight with an elastic band around it.
And I was a superb passer with one of those until they gave me a real football and I found I couldn't handle the thing.
What about brothers and sisters?
I have none.
Would you say again how you got to Rensselaer Tech?
Rensselaer Polytech?
By the time I was about a junior in high school, I knew what I wanted.
I wanted to become an engineer for a number of reasons.
For one thing, engineering didn't require the background of the so-called cultural topics.
literature, great literature that you normally think of as a child having at home was not available in our house or anybody else's homes.
Yet I had an ability with mathematics and I loved abstractions.

And about this time I decided I wanted to go into an engineering college and so I looked around and the traditional schools in that area would have been Rutgers, NYU, New York University, CCNY, although that was not available to me.
That was only available for
New York City residents, Brooklyn Polytech, and of course I'd heard about Rensselaer, didn't know much about it.
I did want one thing, I wanted to get away from home.
I just felt, you know, the confines of Jersey City were beginning to get to me.
I wanted to get away from that area.
There wasn't that much there, plus the fact that I watched the poverty, which I began now to perceive,
And I wanted to break out of the mold of Jersey City.

The normal mold for me, or for most of the people in the downtown area, would have been to finish high school, for those who were fortunate, most often not quit at 16, and go to work on the docks, or go to work in the railroad yard, or go to work in the slaughterhouses.
And it was like a great pit staring in front of me, and I wanted to avoid it as much as possible.
And you can't appreciate what it means until you've been there.
It's like a nightmare, a constant recurring nightmare, somebody saying, well, you're doing good, but wait, we're going to get you.
You're coming back.
And I didn't know this.
I did not want that kind of an existence.
It's as though somebody were just chasing after me, and I just had to run and run and run and do everything I could to get away from it.
And Rensselaer seemed to have been the furthest away of all the schools that I was aware of when I applied.
not hoping or didn't even think that they might take me, but I thought nothing could be lost by applying, and when I applied, lo and behold, they accepted me.
For what reasons, I have no idea.
Do you remember how the ward bosses affected the lives of the newly-aroused immigrants?
Oh, yeah.
The greatest system that we've ever had, in spite of what you hear about.
You know, we talk now about modern society being uncommunicative and modern leaders being removed from society.

Hague's machine, and for that matter the machines in all of the cities, were as corrupt as they can be in that people did take money, but they never took money away from the mouths of the people, especially from the poor.
And the ward, of course, existed not because of the wealthy or the middle class.
It existed because the immigrants or the poor.
Once you established yourself as a Democrat, because there were no Republicans in Jersey City, at least I never was aware of any, you never had to worry about food.
If you were in dire need, in starvation, the ward boss would be the one who would take care of you.
He would make sure that either companies or perhaps the city would provide food for you.
Where there was a possibility of a job, even though it was makeshift work, you'd have some money coming in.
And it was a very humane type of existence.
That is, they literally looked after their own because the ward bosses themselves were nothing more than just part of the people.
And the ward boss lived right there among the people.
He was one of you.
He probably lived three or four more houses down in a cold water flat, which is where most of us lived.
And so if you had a problem, you went to him, and he knew exactly what it was that you were talking about.
He, in turn, would have the influence then into City Hall.
And City Hall depended on its votes from the poor.

Now, the bad part about it is, if you happen to be a free spirit and suddenly started to mouth off and said, I'm going to clean up the government, or I hereby claim myself as a Republican, or some other nonsensical thing that a luxury that is really limited to the middle class, you found yourself
on a very brutal end of the stick.
Because as charitable as they could be, they would not brook any rebellion.
They would come down on you pretty hard.
And by that I mean physically.
The cops would visit you and proceed to work you over.
And it wasn't unusual for people to disappear.
But by and large, most people didn't do that.
Most people weren't.
Most people, the politics part,
was the last thing away from their mind.
The important thing was survival and how to keep the family together.
This continued through the 30s?
This continued right into the 40s, and in fact, the last vestige of it was Mayor Daley.
Mayor Daley was the last of the great city bosses.
He lived right among the people.
He understood the people.
The problem was that he may have stayed on perhaps one generation too late because once the first generation grew up,
second-generation started to move outside of the city.
It started now to expand.
After the Second World War, suburbs started to come into being.
The working man became a middle-class citizen and could afford things, which meant the concentration of people diminished.
And when that happened, at least that would have been one of the reasons that caused the demise of the city force.
But if you were to ask, how do I judge it?
Was it a successful political system?
I would say superbly.
It satisfied the demands and the needs of the people at the time they most needed it.
And during the Depression, it was a particularly good system.
In downtown Jersey City, people would have starved had it not been for the ward bosses and for the pressure that they would put on the industries in the city.
Then you think the ward bosses had more of an effect on stabilizing the Jersey City area than did the New Deal programs?
Well, yes, I do.
The New Deal program was an overview program.
The New Deal program would have meant nothing at all to anybody unless it was implemented.
The ward bosses perhaps were the most important single item.
The New Deal helped give the whole country a different direction.
But if the New Deal had not come in, say Roosevelt had not won,
The people in the cities would have still survived because you still had your big city bosses and you still had your ward system.
And your ward system did exist during Republican as well as Democratic administrations.
It would have been a little bit harder, but it would have still continued on.
What the New Deal did is, of course, create WPA.
And WPA in turn was administered through the city and finally ultimately dispensed by the ward bosses.
So in my view, the ward system was perhaps the single most important stabilizing element for the immigrants in this country.
Do you have any indication how politics of Jersey City has changed since you were there in the 30s as a boy?
Yeah.
For one thing, you have now two new ethnic groups.
You have the Puerto Ricans and you have the Negroes.
The downtown area
is almost totally replaced by those.
There are a few small pockets of either Polish or Italian ethnic areas.
But it's changed.
A number of things have come into being.
For one thing, at least for the whites, there's a middle class basis which didn't exist in the 30s.
The cohesiveness of the people perhaps has also changed now than it was in the 30s and in the 40s.
When you didn't have transportation, mass transportation, when you didn't have all of the possibilities for recreation, people tended to live in their own immediate environments.
The streets and the city block was not only a place to sleep or walk, it was also a place to play, it was a place of culture.
And you had a whole cultural dimension known as the inner city block.
which in many cases still exists now, but it exists among the Negroes and the Puerto Ricans.
And to really see it would mean that you would have to go there and understand it.
Now within the, say, the Negro community, you find a great deal of violence associated with it.
Violence in the sense of guns and knives and things of this sort.
There was violence in the sense that there would be an occasional fight, fist fight, and at worst a pool cue.
but I cannot remember violence of the nature that you see here.
And of course, many sociologists have said that it's because of the background of the people, the cultural background of the people.
I'm not sure I buy that, quite frankly, because again, when you talk with a peasant, you're not talking with an aristocratic individual who could look back at family.
But in contrast to the minority now, the elements that you see now, with the exception of the Spanish,
There was a cohesiveness of family, which the Negro is now just beginning to establish.
So I'm not quite sure how you'd put that in perspective.
There are differences.
Now, Jersey City is different now.
Has there been any change in the second generation of immigrants?
Has there been any movement away from the Democratic Party by that group compared to their fathers and mothers?
Yeah, there has been.
As you get into the middle class syndrome, you find that you begin objecting to the amount of money taken out of your paycheck.
You suddenly begin enjoying the luxuries of life, and you begin objecting to have to share them.

And you find that you more and more tend to lean toward a Republican view, which means keep government off my back, rather than a Democratic one, which is basically get government in because it's a great help.
So there has been that movement.
Now, how much, I don't know.
Tell us about your years at Rensselaer.
There's not really much to say.
You entered in what, 1941?
I graduated in 52.
I was a very serious student and very much aware that in my family this was the first time that anybody has ever gone through high school, let alone go to college.
And I was aware of both the responsibility as well as the fears
My father was able to scrape enough money to put me through.
The tuition at that time was $750 a year, which was a considerable amount of money.
And so I tried to minimize costs.
My clothes were all Army surplus.
This was the post-war years where you could get fairly nice surplus clothes.
The officer pink twills was the standard sports costume for most people on campuses in those days.
Would you say that again?
Pink twills.
Spell that.
P-I-N-K.
T-W-I-L-L-S. Two words.
Yeah, they're twills.
They were gabardine trousers that officers would wear and that were sold in a surplus equipment.
You got surplus jackets, surplus shirts, and so I lived that way.
My food was very sparse.
In fact, I think I lived on beans most of the time.
I never went out on Saturday and Sunday.
I was what you'd call a drudge.
I worked and studied seven days a week and enjoyed it.
For me, it was as though I entered into a new land, and there was just a tremendous sense of excitement, of learning.
And so I spent four years without really having much of a social life, other than working and working and working away.
But I graduated with honors, and I never regret those four years.
They were not what you'd call a traditional high school or college experience, because I didn't go out on dates, didn't go out to fraternities, even though they did exist.
I had very few friends, pretty much people the same as I.
And most of all, enjoyed what I was doing, enjoyed just studying, enjoyed just expanding my mind and standing in awe of the opportunity that was given to me.
Okay, what happened in 52 when you completed?
Well, then I graduated and I went to Curtis Wright Corporation.
I worked in the...
Okay, in St. Louis?
No, Caldwell, New Jersey.
Caldwell, New Jersey.
Yeah, they had a propeller division there.
And I worked there for two years.
And, of course, this was now getting on toward the tail end of the Korean War.
And I remember I reported to the draft board, and they said, well, you're working for an essential industry.
I said, fine.
And then they came around and they drafted me, and that's perhaps not quite true.
In reality, about 54, I went to the draft board, and I said, will you draft me?
They said, yes, whether you want to go.
I told them, well, how about spring?
It seems a nice time.
I worked at Curtis Wright.
And of course, Curtis Wright was a great employer of Rensselaer students.
And many of the people working in this small office, the same as the machine design office, were people that had preceded me by a year or so.
And I knew were honor students of themselves.
And I watched what they were doing.
And what struck me is that here were people highly motivated in college, very capable, who did nothing more than live for the weekend.
They would talk about what they did last weekend.
They would talk about what they were going to do the following weekend.
Would come in at 8 o'clock and would leave promptly at 5 o'clock.
And that was not what, in my mind, I had studied for.
I didn't want an 8 to 5 job.
It had to be more than that.
It had to be a consuming passion.
Perhaps at that age I still thought of those terms.
Perhaps I still do.
I began to become very disillusioned with the practice of engineering as I had seen it at Curtis Wright, and I decided I need to get away and see, is this really what I want to do?
And so when I asked them to draft me, it was, in a sense, my escape route.
It was a legitimate way of leaving, doing something that I would never again do in my life, playing soldier, but most of all, giving me the time to think what I wanted to do.
And so I was drafted.
On May the 3rd, 1954, I went to Fort Dix, did my basic, then I went to Fort Huachuca, and then finally to Gila Bend.
Spell it, Fort Huachuca.
H-U-A-C-H-U-K-A.
My father never could pronounce it.
He always called it Fort Hoochie Coochie.
Located in where?
It's located in Arizona, south.
In fact, I think it's a town of its own now.
It's located around, well, south of Tombstone.
and I'd leave west of Douglas.
How long were you in the Army?
Two years.
You spent the whole time in Arizona?
Yeah.
In 1956 you got out.
What did you do then?
I went to graduate school at Ohio State.
The original idea was... Columbus?
I got out a little earlier.
I got out, I think, 60 days earlier than two years because the Army at that time had a policy
that you could get out up to ninety days early if you could show that a school had begun within that period of time or you had seasonal occupation.
And after two years at Gila Bend I decided it's time now to leave.
I got my act pretty much together.
I know what I want to do.
And I started to look at graduate schools and somebody mentioned Ohio State and Ohio State was under a quarter system which meant that they started
their semester on March the 16th.
So I applied for early leave, was granted it, and went to Columbus, Ohio, and did my master's.
Having done my master's, finished it, I was offered an instructorship and asked to continue on for my doctorate.
When did you complete the master's?
In 19, let's see, I got out at 56, 57.
And then you worked at Ohio State?
Right, as an instructor.
I worked on my doctorate at the same time.
When did you complete the doctorate?
You stayed there through that time?
Yeah.
At Ohio State?
Yeah, from 57 to 62.
When did you marry?
I married in 58.
Where was your wife from?
She was originally from Ridgeway, but she was a graduate student.
Ridgeway where?
Pennsylvania.
She was a graduate student pursuing doctoral studies at Ohio State in the Department of History.
In fact, when I was finishing up my master's, she had just finished her prelims for her PhD.
We met and we married in 1958, a year after we met, about a year and a half after we met.
My wife was working on a dissertation.
And after we married, she decided that no,
Really, the dissertation was not what she was interested in.
For one thing, it was a rather boring subject.
As she now freely admits, had the subject been more exciting, she probably would have continued.

But instead, since she did have a teaching certificate, she then went and taught in the public schools in Columbus, also taught at Ohio Wesleyan University, which is close to Columbus, and then worked as a secretary part-time jobs.
Could you tell us why you chose mechanical engineering rather than another field of engineering?
Well, I didn't choose mechanical engineering.
My bachelor's was in aeronautical engineering, and my master's and my doctorate were in flight mechanics.
Those were the areas that I enjoyed.
When I came to A&M, there was no flight mechanics department.
There was a program called M&M, Mechanics and Materials, or at that time SM, Structural Mechanics.
And I came to the Mechanical Engineering Department because it was the closest thing to my interest.
In 1962, you completed your doctorate.
What did you do then?
I stayed on at Ohio State for that year as an assistant professor.
I was tenured, still in applied mechanics, where I did, in fact, the same department I did my graduate work in.
I was tenured by that time because the rank of instructor, which I held for five years, was a tenure-track position.
And after four years, you were granted tenure.
So I had tenure and an assistant professorship.
But I decided that staying on at the institution where you got your degree was not the best policy.
And so we then proceeded to look at universities throughout the country.
And like most people, sent out something like 75 letters
and received a number of responses.
And A&M was one of them.
And we looked at what A&M had, what it offered, and I decided I wanted to come to A&M.
So you came here in 63?
63, right.
You've been here ever since.
Right.
As a professor, I came in as an associate professor.
I became a full professor in 67 and continued on.
And you've been involved in teaching and research.
Right.
You haven't held administrative posts?
No.
Did you find that when you came to Texas A&M that you were discriminated against by your northern background?
No, I got the usual jokes.
And in fact, the very first one that I came
In fact, the first year we came, they had two snows at College Station.
And I remember they were telling me about a Blue Northern.
I had never heard of this before.
And finally, this was in about September.
It was an unusually hot September, October.
And when the Blue Northern came, it dropped the temperature from about 95 to about 89.
And everybody said, now isn't it cool?
And I looked at him, and I told him, the only other Blue Northern that you've ever seen was Grant.
And he came marching in from Georgia.
But I never had any problems because of the Northern background or the accent.
What are some of the research projects that you've been involved in in the 18 years that you've been here?
Well, there were the NASA projects and this was, at that time, the Manned Spacecraft Center, which is now Johnson Spacecraft Center.
In the 60s, shell structures, which was the outer skin, was a critical element.
And at that time, they were still trying to develop techniques by which to analyze these type of structures and assure against any failure.

And so from about 63 to about 71, I was directly working with the Manned Spacecraft Center, funded by them, to do work, both theoretical and practical, on developing ways of analyzing reinforced shell structures.
About 69, the project Themis came into being.
This was the idea of helping schools, just building research programs, develop competence.
And this was funded by the Department of Defense.
And A&M was one of the recipients of one of these grants.
And I defined for them a program in the College of Engineering dealing with the optimization of reinforced shells.
And that is, if you're going to reinforce it and put stiffeners, what is the most efficient way of doing it so you gain your strength at a minimum increase in weight?
And that program then brought in industry.
China, not Charles Ford, but up in the Fort Worth area, there's Charles Ford and there's Convair.
General Dynamics, rather.
The General Dynamics people were extremely interested in it because in that time they were developing the composites program.

The composite being just now a material that is coming into its own, but in those days it was a very exotic type of material, very high cost, but the Air Force was extremely interested in it because it gave stiffness properties, strength properties, and very, very little weight.
And it also had another feature that is now beginning to be mentioned, and that is it was invisible to radar.
And so we brought them into the project because, again, composites were a means of reinforcing shells.
That monies ended about 1971, about the time Nixon cut back all type of funding.
And so for a period of time, from about 71 to 74, I did various things, research, again within shells,
